bibl.title: Letter from Harvey P. Barret to Henry Rose Carter, April 8, 1918

div1.p: Barret informs Carter that Aedes Canadensis mosquitos do feed on humans.

div1.head: Letter from Harvey P. Barret to Henry Rose Carter, April 8, 1918
div1.opener:
Miss
Barrett
Aides
Canadense
The New Charlotte Sanatorium
Charlotte, N. C.
Apr. 8th, 1918
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of Apr. 3rd, has just
come this morning. In answer to your question
about Aedes Canadensis will say that the imagoes
undoubtedly do bite men, and bite hard too. This
has been my personal experience around the breeding
places. I dont recall ever having been bitten around
dwelling places or in other places than in the immediate
vicinity of breeding places. In regard to breeding
places, it is our commonest species here from early
Spring to Midsummer and in the fields and woods.
You wouldnt have any trouble identifying it, at least'
not in telling it from some of the other species,
by the bands on all three pairs of legs. I would be
mighty glad to get any of your larvae and try and
identify them if you cared to send them. Tho of course
the Washington men could give you a lot better service.
I will write you soon about the Anopheles in answer to
your letter of Apr. 1st. With best wishes, I am
div1.closer: Sincerely, Harvey P Barret 1915 Pqrk Drive.
